newGraph

public static Graph newGraph(GraphQueryResult theResult)
                      throws QueryEvaluationException
Create a Sesame graph from the GraphQueryResult. The query result is always closed regardless of whether or not it was successfully transformed into a graph.

Parameters:
theResult - the result of the query
Returns:
the graph built from the result
Throws:
QueryEvaluationException - if there was an error while creating the graph from the query result

withContext

public static Graph withContext(Graph theGraph,
                                Resource theResource)
Returns a copy of the provided graph where all the statements belong to the specified context. This will overwrite any existing contexts on the statements in the graph.

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theResource - the context for all the statements in the graph
Returns:
the new graph

union

public static Graph union(Graph... theGraphs)
Return a new Graph which is the union of all the provided graphs. Be careful if you are using statements w/ a context as the equals method for Statement does not take into account context, so two statements with the same SPO, but different contexts will be considered the same statement and only one will be included in the union. You can use ContextAwareStatement which implements equals & hashcode taking into account the context if you need to use Statements with contexts where context is considered in this way.

Parameters:
theGraphs - the graphs to union
Returns:
the union of the graphs

contextGraph

public static Graph contextGraph()
Return a new (empty) graph whose ValueFactory is an instance of ContextAwareValueFactory

Returns:
a new "context aware" graph

contextGraph

public static Graph contextGraph(Graph theGraph)
Return a new context graph copying the contents of the provided graph into the new graph so that all of its statements are instances of ContextAwareStatement.

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph to copy
Returns:
the copied graph, but context aware

Parameters:
theGraph - the Graph
thePredicate - the predicate
Returns:

collect

public static <T> java.util.Collection<T> collect(java.lang.Iterable<Statement> theGraph,
                                                  com.google.common.base.Function<Statement,com.google.common.base.Optional<T>> theFunction)
Collect the results of the Function as it is applied to each Statement. Absent values are not collected; the provided function should never return a null value.

Parameters:
theGraph - the statements
theFunction - the function
Returns:
the collected values

Collect the results of the Function as it is applied to each Statement. Absent values are not collected; the provided function should never return a null value.

Parameters:
theStatementIterator - the statements
theFunction - the function
Returns:
the collected values

getObject

public static com.google.common.base.Optional<Value> getObject(Graph theGraph,
                                                               Resource theSubj,
                                                               URI thePred)
Return the value of the property for the given subject. If there are multiple values, only the first value will be returned. Use GraphUtil.getObjectIterator(org.openrdf.model.Graph, org.openrdf.model.Resource, org.openrdf.model.URI, org.openrdf.model.Resource...) if you want all values for the property.

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theSubj - the subject
thePred - the property of the subject whose value should be retrieved
Returns:
optionally, the value of the the property for the subject
See Also:
GraphUtil.getOptionalObject(org.openrdf.model.Graph, org.openrdf.model.Resource, org.openrdf.model.URI, org.openrdf.model.Resource...)

getLiteral

public static com.google.common.base.Optional<Literal> getLiteral(Graph theGraph,
                                                                  Resource theSubj,
                                                                  URI thePred)
Return the value of of the property as a Literal

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theSubj - the resource
thePred - the property whose value is to be retrieved
Returns:
Optionally, the property value as a literal. Value will be absent of the SP does not have an O, or the O is not a literal
See Also:
getObject(org.openrdf.model.Graph, org.openrdf.model.Resource, org.openrdf.model.URI)

getResource

public static com.google.common.base.Optional<Resource> getResource(Graph theGraph,
                                                                    Resource theSubj,
                                                                    URI thePred)
Return the value of of the property as a Resource

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theSubj - the resource
thePred - the property whose value is to be retrieved
Returns:
Optionally, the property value as a Resource. Value will be absent of the SP does not have an O, or the O is not a Resource
See Also:
getObject(org.openrdf.model.Graph, org.openrdf.model.Resource, org.openrdf.model.URI), GraphUtil.getOptionalObjectResource(org.openrdf.model.Graph, org.openrdf.model.Resource, org.openrdf.model.URI)

getBooleanValue

public static com.google.common.base.Optional<java.lang.Boolean> getBooleanValue(Graph theGraph,
                                                                                 Resource theSubj,
                                                                                 URI thePred)
Returns the value of the property on the given resource as a boolean.

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theSubj - the resource
thePred - the property
Returns:
Optionally, the value of the property as a boolean. Value will be absent if the SP does not have an O, or that O is not a literal or not a valid boolean value

isList

public static boolean isList(Graph theGraph,
                             Resource theRes)
Returns whether or not the given resource is a rdf:List

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theRes - the resource to check
Returns:
true if its a list, false otherwise

asList

public static java.util.List<Value> asList(Graph theGraph,
                                           Resource theRes)
Return the contents of the given list by following the rdf:first/rdf:rest structure of the list

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theRes - the resource which is the head of the list
Returns:
the contents of the list.

                                                    Resource theRes)
Return an Iterable of the types of the Resource in the specified Graph

Parameters:
theGraph - the graph
theRes - the resource
Returns:
the asserted rdf:type's of the resource
